div.h1: Visualizing computational, transversal narratives from the World Trade Towers

div.div: Departments of English and Communication, Georgia State University
Search for other works by this author on:

Department of English, Georgia State University

Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue 2, June 2017, Pages 344–354, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw004

div.p: Ben Miller, Ayush Shrestha, Jennifer Olive, Visualizing computational, transversal narratives from the World Trade Towers, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue 2, June 2017, Pages 344–354, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw004

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Semi-automated extraction of details corresponding to narratological fabula from a corpus of narrative interviews on a single event provides decontextualized building blocks for transversal, or cross-document, narratives. With information extracted from 503 World Trade Center Task Force Interviews comprising 12,000 pages of testimony and novel visualization techniques, this article proposes a computational method for the emergence of narratives that cross beyond the boundaries of one interview. These assembled narratives, in cases like that of Chief Ganci, can document those who did not survive to tell their own story.
